hedline.hl1: A Diner's Latest Incarnation, With Children's Fare Too

abstract.p: Purity Diner reopens at new location, Seventh Avenue and Seventh Street in Brooklyn (New Yorkers & Co column) (S)

block.p: The Purity Diner is reopening in Park Slope, Brooklyn, this time at 289 Seventh Avenue (at Seventh Street). The restaurant, which offers standard diner fare like Belgian waffles, eggs, sandwiches, salads and burgers, as well as a children's menu, was at 100 Seventh Avenue (at Union Street) from 1929 until the end of last year. (It was originally called the Purity Restaurant and was named the New Purity Restaurant in 1986.)

The restaurant, which offers standard diner fare like Belgian waffles, eggs, sandwiches, salads and burgers, as well as a children's menu, was at 100 Seventh Avenue (at Union Street) from 1929 until the end of last year. (It was originally called the Purity Restaurant and was named the New Purity Restaurant in 1986.)

''The landlord would not renew our lease,'' said Chris Mihalislis, who manages the new location with her husband, Gus. ''He just didn't want a restaurant there anymore,'' she added. She and her husband have had 33 restaurants in the 28 years they have been married. They now own four, as well as a bar, all in Brooklyn.
